executive_summary: Figures have been adjusted for inflation and are presented in 2024 currency. An array of downstream industries in the manufacturing and construction sectors use ferrous metal foundry products. These markets were weakened at the start of the current period due to declining industrial activity. In addition, fluctuating raw material prices have contributed to a rising level of revenue volatility. Also, the industry has recently struggled to maintain growth and profit during the systematic shock to economic activity and global trade stemming from the pandemic.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Rising Input Costs, Such as the World Price of Iron Ore Add to Weak Profit
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: The price foundries pay for ferrous metal inputs significantly impacts the final costs they charge buyers for these goods. Foundries will attempt to pass higher input costs onto customers. The world price of iron ore and the price of steel, which form a significant portion of industry expenses, are notoriously volatile and challenging for manufacturers to manage. The world price of iron ore has increased through 2024 because of the significant appetite for iron from rapidly developing nations, namely India and China.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: The Construction Markets Struggle to Generate Growth
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Rising interest rates have slashed demand from construction markets following the pandemic. The value of residential construction has declined despite solid growth in 2020, as people can't fund new projects. In addition, housing starts have lagged in the latter part of the period due to rising interest rates. Similarly, the value of nonresidential construction crashed during the pandemic as office vacancies rose. Rising interest rates make new construction projects unprofitable even as individuals return to work.

The automotive sector is among the industry's largest markets, representing a significant consumer of ductile iron castings. Similar to the construction markets, substitute materials, like aluminum, have grown popular. Iron and steel casting are often heavier and less malleable than alternatives. As automotive manufacturers produce lighter bodies to hit fuel efficiency targets, this critical source of revenue will wane.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Domestic Foundries Invest in Niche Products Less Vulnerable to Price Competition
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: To combat rising competition from substitutes and international foundries, companies will cater to small-order, high-precision and custom-made products. These include products with complex shapes, greater core complexities, tighter dimensional tolerances and specialty-grade corrosion-resistant steels. These parts often require a high degree of technical collaboration with customers and flexible lead times that are less vulnerable to price competition. In these markets, reputation and delivery time become significantly more important.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: INFRASTRUCTURE SPENDING WILL SUPPORT CONSTRUCTION MARKETS
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: As the domestic population grows, significant investments are needed to maintain the country's aging infrastructure. In particular, water and sewage systems will need new pipes. The Infrastructure Investment and Jobs Act (IIJA) will provide funding for updates and new facilities by the construction sector, specifically utilities construction. Also, public support for cleaner and more sustainable alternatives will result in new plants and facilities. Even so, iron and steel foundry products will face direct competition from readily available and affordable plastic pipes.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: DOMESTIC FOUNDRIES GAIN GROUND AGAINST IMPORTS
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: International trade is subject to significant volatility as global supply chains remain in disarray and many countries, like China, continue to battle flare-ups of the coronavirus. Domestic companies will jump at the opportunity to expand their presence into foreign markets, fulfilling supply shortfalls and raising competition among manufacturers to sway international customers in major export destinations, including Mexico and Canada. Even so, many downstream markets have opted for offshore production. As these customers move abroad, they will source inputs from nearby suppliers in foreign markets instead of domestic foundries.

industry_definition: Companies in this industry pour molten iron and steel into molds of a desired shape to make castings. Companies purchase ferrous metal inputs from iron.

positive_impact_factors: high - steady Barriers To Entry Level

key_trends: Competitive pricing is critical to attracting buyers in a low-margin industry. Foundries must deliver a wide range of high-quality products.
Many foundries have direct links to downstream markets. It's difficult for new entrants to unseat companies with existing relationships with buyers.
Rising input prices coupled with contracting downstream markets have slammed ferrous metal foundries. Companies can't raise prices enough to offset downward pressure on profit.
Foundries have shifted custom-made products, enabling companies to move into niche product segments. These customized products will elevate profit for ferrous metal foundries.
Established companies have the benefit of long-standing contracts with downstream markets. Smaller entrants have to contend with heavy price competition from larger foundries.

Waupaca and Precision Castparts have each captured more than 9.0% of the market by offering a wide variety of high-quality products and delivering shipments on time. These companies operate several product lines that service construction and manufacturing industries, while smaller foundries serve local and niche markets.

Ferrous metal foundry product manufacturers face heavy environmental regulations. Major regulations include the Clear Water Act, Resource Conservation and Recovery Act and Clean Air Act enforced by the EPA.
Rising inflation will throw downstream markets into disarray. The automotive and construction sectors will inhibit growth as economic uncertainty increases.
Foundries are heavily reliant on input prices. Profit has lagged due to significant purchase costs.
Despite mechanization initiatives, labor costs remain high. Manufacturers require skilled workers to operate complex machinery properly.
Many foundries will locate near the manufacturing sector, the industry's largest market. Many downstream manufacturers are in the Great Lakes and West regions.
Access to labor is vital since the industry is labor-intensive. The Southeast region has greater access to workers than other areas.
The construction and transportation manufacturing markets have contracted. The prevalence of alternatives and economic uncertainty has forced buyers to cut back on ferrous metal foundry products.
Iron foundry products make up the majority of sales. Iron has many applications and comes at a lower price than steel or alternatives like aluminum, copper or magnesium.

market_segmentation.segment_description: The Ferrous Metal Foundry Products industry manufactures a range of iron and steel castings for industrial machinery and equipment. Sales are evenly split between iron and steel castings. Mining and construction businesses use castings in the manufacturing of tractor-crawlers, mining trucks, excavators, draglines, wheel loaders, rock crushers, diesel engines, slurry pumps, coal-mining machines and ore-processing equipment.

The share of revenue generated by sales of ferrous castings to machinery and general manufacturing industries has steadily grown as demand for agricultural and defense machinery increased and has offset falling demand for residential construction machinery.

Downstream construction markets primarily use pipes and fillings consisting of ductile iron. Residential construction markets demanded more building materials in the first half of the current period as funding from the public sector increased to help stimulate building activity. Investment in nonresidential construction has fallen significantly since the pandemic's beginning and delaying many projects during the period.

This sector uses ferrous castings, predominantly steel and investment cast steel, to produce goods like metal valves, small arms, saw blades and hand tools. Within this market, valve manufacturers are the largest consumers of steel castings. These buyers use valves in numerous infrastructure projects, including petroleum production and pipeline transmission, water systems, power generation and electric utilities, commercial and residential building piping systems and other applications.

products_and_services.product_description: Iron foundry products account for the single-largest product segment within the Ferrous Metal Foundry Products industry, comprising over one-half of revenue in 2024. This segment's share of physical output is even larger, at nearly 90.0%, reflecting the lower price of iron castings compared with steel castings.

Companies covet steel investment foundries for their ability to produce more complex designs with tighter tolerances and superior surface finishes than steel foundry products manufactured via sand casting. Investment casting also destroys the mold used in the casting process, whereas traditional casting reuses the mold.

This segment consists of corrosion-resistant (alloy) steel, commoditized (carbon) steel and other steel castings. Steel castings have better strength, ductility, heat resistance and durability than iron castings.

demand_determinants.determinant_description: Demand for alloy steel from the manufacturing sector, especially automotive industries, has hindered this segment. In addition, carbon steel sales have declined during the current period as its more susceptible to rust and corrosion.

international_trade_points.trade_title: Domestic buyers choose low-priced, high-volume foreign supply
international_trade_points.trade_description: China and India are important sources of relatively low-value, high-volume, commodity-type iron castings, used primarily in construction applications. These lower-wage countries have a price advantage compared with local producers.

international_trade_points.trade_title: A rising US dollar keeps imports from declining more
international_trade_points.trade_description: Domestic demand and the appreciating dollar have limited import volume declines in the latter half of the five-year period. Imports will continue to lag in the outlook period, as the US dollar weakens and returns to its historical equilibrium, making imports more expensive.

Between 2009 and 2011, the industry benefited from a trade surplus, largely the result of strong demand for ferrous metal foundry products in emerging economies. Since then, China and India have become major producers of ferrous metal foundry products. These regions have supplied emerging economies across Asia and Africa, eliminating most of domestic manufacturers' power.

international_trade_points.trade_title: United States-Mexico-Canada Agreement (USMCA) limits declines in exports
international_trade_points.trade_description: Over one-half of all domestic exports end up in Mexico or Canada, as the USMCA trade deal has lowered transportation costs and set up favorable tariffs between the three nations. The USMCA especially benefits Canada, which imports the fourth-most ferrous metal foundry products to the United States and takes in nearly one-half of all domestic exports.

business_locations.location_description: Metal casting companies are located in areas that enable them to take advantage of proximity to raw materials, coal and water for cooling, processing and transportation. The region's importance reflects the fact that key customers, like the automotive industry, and key suppliers, including the steel industry, are also heavily skewed toward that region. Canada is also a primary trade partner in the Aluminum Manufacturing industry, with establishments in the Great Lakes region using their proximity to facilitate trade with Canada.

Southeastern states typically have more lenient regulations in place, luring numerous manufacturers into setting up operations in the region. The Southeast region has the highest population in the United States, making it easier for companies to acquire labor. Also, the Southeast region boasts easy, low-cost access to electricity. Many of the industry's processes are highly energy-intensive.

Population dispersion, general economic activity and construction investment influences the location of foundries. California's high population makes it a key market for ferrous casting materials in the state's flourishing manufacturing and construction markets.

regulations_points.regulation_description: The Clean Air Act requires compliance with air quality standards and empowers the Environmental Protection Agency to establish and enforce limits on the emission of pollutants. The EPA sets allowances for sulfur and nitrogen oxides and strict requirements applicable to ozone emissions and other toxic materials. The Clean Water Act regulates the discharge of pollutants into surface water; the act establishes a system of minimum national efficiency standards on an industry-to-industry basis, water quality standards and a discharge permit program.

regulations_points.regulation_title: The Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA)
regulations_points.regulation_description: Foundries are also subject to various nonenvironmental matters, including occupational health and safety, wage, overtime and other employment matters dealing with state and federal government agencies. Employees must put on personal protective equipment, train employees in using all machines, review safe production techniques and certify machinery. OSHA has enforced fines of half a million dollars on manufacturers that don't follow these restrictions or whose negligence harms employees.

In response to the pandemic, federal, state and local policymakers imposed regulations on many public and business activities. The Ferrous Metal Foundry Products industry dealt with an uneven national shutdown as many states originally designated industry functions as nonessential, requiring manufacturers to reduce production immediately. Even though many states have cleared businesses to operate since the outset of the pandemic, many manufacturers continue to scale back or modify business practices to accommodate new health and safety regulations at workplaces.

barriers_points.barrier_description: Environmental legislation and regulation at the state and federal levels are significant legal barriers since foundries often produce hazardous materials as externalities. To operate in the industry, foundries require approval from federal and state governments.
Existing players have close-knit relationships with customers, making it difficult, if not impossible, for a new foundry to attract a stable customer.
High costs are associated with the construction, development and operation of a new foundry. Most prospective entrants lack the necessary capital to enter the market.
Smaller foundries rely on labor more than large-scale mass producers since small producers lack the capital to mechanize production. Unskilled labor is essential for assembly line work.

concentration_points.concentration_title: EXCLUSIVE PARTNERSHIPS LIMIT MARKET SHARE GROWTH
concentration_points.concentration_description: The low concentration level reflects the custom-made nature of much of the industry's output and the consequent lack of available economies of scale. The largest foundries can't grow their market share because they have agreed to exclusive partnerships.

Consolidation is increasing as smaller, unprofitable foundries are acquired by larger competitors or forced to leave the industry altogether. Larger foundries also acquire smaller competitors to strengthen supply relations with existing clients. While some larger companies may continue to acquire smaller players over the coming years, the overall effect on concentration will be limited.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Input Prices such as Iron and Steel remain Volatile
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: The price of raw materials, primarily iron and steel, to manufacturing casting is a major cost driver for the industry. Purchase costs represent the largest industry expense but have lagged over the past five years.

volatility_points.volatility_title: The industry's key inputs are volatile
volatility_points.volatility_description: Fluctuations in the prices of iron and steel, the two key inputs for manufacturers, have resulted in volatile selling prices and translated into unsteady industry revenue.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Manufacturers rely on downstream manufacturing and construction industries
volatility_points.volatility_description: Activity in the manufacturing and construction sectors drives demand. Falling industrial activity contributes to low demand for ferrous castings and falling prices for material inputs like steel.

technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Many foundries have shifted to exclusive partnerships with existing customers to develop niche, high-precision products. These products will create steady revenue generation and strengthen the relationship between buyer and foundry, making it harder for a new entrant to disrupt existing relationships.

FAQs.question: How have imports from low-wage countries such as China and Mexico impacted your operations?
FAQs.answer: Imports satisfy a relatively low share of domestic demand, as foundries' production process requires high purchaser-manufacturer interface.

FAQs.question: Have exports offered an opportunity for your company?
FAQs.answer: Exports make up a very small share of industry revenue. This is due to rising production capacity abroad and decelerating growth in foreign construction markets.

FAQs.question: Has your company been exposed to volatile input prices over the past few years?
FAQs.answer: The key inputs for this industry are iron ore and steel. The price of both of these inputs is inherently volatile.

FAQs.question: Is your company located near important suppliers or key downstream industries?
FAQs.answer: The most highly concentrated region of industry establishments is the Great Lakes region, as it offers operators ease of access to key suppliers of input materials. Minimizing transportation costs can play a decisive role in a company's profitability.

FAQs.question: How is your company leveraging new technology?
FAQs.answer: The industry has made some minor technological advances in recent years, particularly in relation to the computer control of machinery and equipment.

FAQs.question: Have you been able to reduce wage costs through automation over the past five years?
FAQs.answer: Despite technological innovations, the Ferrous Metal Foundry Products industry remains a highly labor-intensive industry relative to other primary metal product industries. Additional technologies implemented to cut wage costs while also improving efficiency stands to benefit the industry's financial performance.

FAQs.question: Have any regulatory expenses significantly impacted profitability recently?
FAQs.answer: Though industry operators are subject to a moderate level of regulation, these regulations generally have a limited impact on profit margin.

FAQs.question: How does your company stay ahead of regulations, such as energy-efficiency standards?
FAQs.answer: Various associations, such as the American Foundry Society and the American Iron and Steel Institute, provide general support and information on regulations pertaining to industry operators.

FAQs.question: How does your company's profit compare with your main competitors'?
FAQs.answer: Profit can vary significantly depending on a company's size. Larger companies regularly post much higher margins than their smaller competitors, as they are able to enter sales contracts and weather periods of input price fluctuation, keeping their selling prices relatively stable.

FAQs.question: How has input price volatility affected profit margins over the past 12 months?
FAQs.answer: Volatile input prices resulted in unstable profit figures, as many operators, especially smaller enterprises, have difficulty securing stable input prices, resulting in fluctuating selling prices.

FAQs.question: What measures do you have in place to reduce operational costs? Are you considering any new cost-saving measures?
FAQs.answer: During and after the casting process, companies perform many tests to monitor and maintain product quality, which helps ensure positive customer relationships and stability of future sales. Companies that can control costs while also scaling production will earn greater profit and outperform industry competitors.

FAQs.question: Have you been able to pass on cost increases to members? What has been members' response to the increases?
FAQs.answer: Engineering and technical professionals are actively involved in marketing and customer service, often working with customers to improve existing products and develop new casting products and applications.

FAQs.question: Does your company use the services of engineering and technical professionals? What new sectors of the economy can you target for expansion?
FAQs.answer: Engineering and technical professionals are actively involved in marketing and customer service, often working with customers to improve existing products and develop new casting products and applications.

FAQs.question: Having a diverse range of clients is important. Customers often develop long-term relationships with foundries that provide high-quality machined castings that are delivered on a just-in-time basis. An increase in customer diversification can help mitigate against losing one specific type of customer, which can help stabilize industry conditions during tumultuous conditions.
FAQs.answer: Having a strong and diverse range of clients is important. Customers often develop long-term relationships with foundries that provide high-quality machined castings that are delivered on a just-in-time basis. An increase in customer diversification can help mitigate against losing one specific type of customer, which can help stabilize industry conditions during tumultuous conditions.

FAQs.question: In what areas of industrial production have you experienced the strongest demand?
FAQs.answer: Iron and steel foundry products are inputs into the production of transportation equipment, machinery, fabricated metal products and pipes. Therefore, as industrial production rises, demand for iron and steel castings grows.

FAQs.question: Does demand for your products trend in line with fluctuations in construction activity? How do you track the value of construction to anticipate changing conditions?
FAQs.answer: Iron castings are heavily used in the construction of highways and roads, pipeline transmission, water systems, power generation and electric utilities.

FAQs.question: How have volatile steel prices affected your company's financial performance? Are you positioned to take advantage of falling steel prices over the coming years?
FAQs.answer: When steel prices climb, manufacturers may be able to pass on some of the higher costs to customers. However, depending on an item's specific price elasticity, companies may not be able to fully offset the increase in cost with an increase in its final selling price, negatively affecting profit. Conversely, when iron and steel prices fall, this may hurt a company's top-line performance if they are unable to generate new sales. However, lower input costs can lead to wider profitability if the company can sustain its current price structure.
